title: NC Tutorial 2 (en)
data:
{"title":"NC Tutorial 2 (en)","nodes":{"0":{"type":"Notes","name":"TUTO 2","x":25,"y":25,"ins":[],"inNames":[],"outNames":[],"params":{"text":"       ---------------------------
      | First Steps in NoiseCraft |
       ---------------------------

Some exercises in manipulating and exploring NoiseCraft functions (or 'nodes').

Move around the main window and the notes using the scroll bars.

All the nodes used in these exercises can be created by clicking on the bottom of the page and selecting them from the list. However, in this first tutorial, the focus will be on manipulating pre-existing nodes.


The notes associated with the exercises tell you more about the functionality of these nodes and about the theory of sound synthesis and music theory in general. These theories can be learned and refined later.

---------------------
Created by (a or not b)"}},"1":{"type":"Notes","name":"Ex 1","x":38,"y":947,"ins":[],"inNames":[],"outNames":[],"params":{"text":"Now move the 'AudioOut' node to the right of the 'Mul' and connect its inputs to the output of the 'Mul', as you learned to do.

Press the '▹Play' button at the top right of the window. And listen to the result. Then press '▫︎Stop'.

1) Change the name ["knob"->"freq"] and the maximum frequency [1->16] of the knob 

Press 'Play' of course to hear what happens when you turn the "freq" knob. Press Stop of course to stop listening. I won't repeat it anymore.

2) Modify the 'Saw' in the same way by clicking on its title to modify its parameters:

minVal: [0->0.6]
maxVal : [1->0.9]

Listen to the result."}},"2":{"type":"Saw","name":"Saw","x":547,"y":956,"ins":[["4",0]],"inNames":["freq"],"outNames":["out"],"params":{"minVal":-1,"maxVal":1}},"4":{"type":"Const","name":"Const","x":457,"y":977,"ins":[],"inNames":[],"outNames":[""],"params":{"value":110}},"5":{"type":"Scope","name":"Scope ,"inNames":["in0","in1"],"outNames":["out"],"params":{}},"157":{"type":"Notes","name":"Ex 0","x":29,"y":257,"ins":[],"inNames":[],"outNames":[],"params":{"text":"Press the '▹Play' button at the top right of the window.

1) Here are the four periodic wave generators available in NoiseCraft.

Their frequency has been set to 0.5 [Hz], in other words their period (the time it takes for them to return to their initial value) is 1[s]/0.5[Hz] = 2[s]

2) Double-click on the title "knob" of the leftmost knob. Change the 'node name' to 'freq' and change its 'maxVal' = 1, to give it the value 110. Validate with the 'Return' key or press 'save'.

3) Increase the 'vol' knob associated with the 'Sine' generator to 1, then turn the 'freq' knob very slowly to its maximum value. Listen and observe the Scope associated with the generator.

3) Turn down the volume of the Sine and repeat with the Tri, Pulse and Saw generators.

When you have finished press '◻︎Stop'."}},"158":{"type":"Notes","name":"Rem 0","x":31,"y":456,"ins":[],"inNames":[],"outNames":[],"params":{"text":"You will notice that by increasing the frequency, from about 20 [hz], the generator produces an audible wave.

You will also notice that not all generators produce the same sound. More precisely, they do not have the same timbre.

This difference of timbre is due to the fact that the air compressed by the movement of your loudspeakers is not compressed in the same way in the 4 cases. In the case of 'Sine' the membrane of your loudspeaker will sink gently, then rise gently, etc. below [-1] and above [+1] its equilibrium value [0], this is not the case in the Pulse and Tri waves where the movements of the membrane are more abrupt.

These "soft" or "abrupt" pressure changes will propagate through the air to reach your eardrums, this is the sound wave.

In theory, each periodic sound wave (which repeats itself) can be analyzed as a more or less large addition of 'Sine' type waves whose frequencies [fN| have harmonic ratios [f2=2*f1 ; f3=3*f1 ; f4=4*f1, etc.], of different amplitudes (and phase [offset]).

see 
https://meettechniek.info/additional/additive-synthesis.html
for a visualization of these additions.

The 'Sine' wave produces only one audible frequency, but the Tri, Pulse and Saw waves produce many more, even if the basic frequency of the generator is the most dominant one because of its greater amplitude (volume)."}},"160":{"type":"Notes","name":"Rem 1","x":39,"y":1147,"ins":[],"inNames":[],"outNames":[],"params":{"text":"The 'Filter' node is a "Lowpass" filter which allows to cut the highest frequencies of a signal (of a sound for example) at a certain cutoff frequency ("cutoff") and to make the frequencies closer to the cutoff frequency resonate ("Resonance"), in other words amplify them.

As you have seen, a greater or lesser number of frequencies contained in the sound generated by the 'Saw' can be cut according to the value of the 'Cutoff'.

Here the 'Saw' wave generator is used to produce a low frequency wave, called "LFO" [Low frequency Oscillator] allowing to MODULATE the value of the 'cutoff' over time.

This manual or automatic modulation (here) of certain parameters of a sound is the essence of the operation of modular synthesizers.

see : 
https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Synth%C3%A9tiseur_modulaire
For more details."}},"161":{"type":"Knob","name":"Resonance","x":788,"y":1110,"ins":[],"inNames":[],"outNames":[""],"params":{"minVal":0,"maxVal":1,"value":0,"deviceId":null,"controlId":null}},"173":{"type":"Notes","name":"Ex 2","x":41,"y":1374,"ins":[],"inNames":[],"outNames":[],"params":{"text":"Add to the following synthesizer (by clicking on the bottom of the page at the appropriate place) :

1) A 'Filter' placed to the right of the 'Add' whose 'cutoff' is modulated by the output of the ADSR.

2) A 'Tri' type LFO (varying between 0.1 and 0.6) whose frequency is determined by a 'const' node with a value of 0.125 [Hz]. It will be connected to the 'sus' (sustain) input of the ADSR.

3)Finally, create a 'Mul' node and its 'OUT VOL' knob (as in exercise 1) on the right, in order to be able to manually manage the output volume of your synthesizer (don't forget to connect your 'AudioOut' of course).

The correction of the exercise is available below."}},"175":{"type":"MonoSeq","name":"MonoSeq","x":548,"y":2071,"ins":[["176",0],["184",0]],"inNames":["clock","gateT"],"outNames":["freq","gate"],"params":{},"scaleName":"natural 2","x":42,"y":1575,"ins":[],"inNames":[],"outNames":[],"params":{"text":"Here you have discovered a new NoiseCaft node: the MonoSeq Sequencer. Like 'GateSeq' it allows you to produce intervals during which the signal produced (gate) goes from 0 to 1. But 'MonoSeq' also allows you to produce sequences of values corresponding to the frequencies of the most common scales (Major, Pentatonic Major, Melodic Minor, Harmonic Minor, etc.)

In this case, the gate activates the ADSR whose sustain value is modulated by 'Tri' in LFO mode. This ADSR will itself modulate, via its envelope, the cutoff frequency of the filter. This is another way of producing an amplitude envelope (and therefore a volume envelope) [see tutorial 1] for a given sound.

As a reminder, the frequency of the highest 'Pulse' has been multiplied by 4 in order to produce the same note as the other 'pulse', but two octaves higher."}},"265":{"type":"Notes","name":"Ex 3","x":50,"y":2793,"ins":[],"inNames":[],"outNames":[],"params":{"text":"(press '‣Play')

1. Create a 'Noise' node on top of the 'Pulse'.

1) Connect it to the 'Noise' scope in front of it. Observe the random shape of the waveform produced.

2) Connect it to the 'Nop' node (a relay node with no effect) and listen to the sound produced.

3) Connect it to the 'in' input of the 'Hold' node and observe the random values varying between -1 and +1 produced every second.

Notice how the 'Add'(+1) will push the random values < 0 above the grey line of the scope (=0)

Notice how the 'Div'(:2) will divide these values varying between 0 and 2 in order to "project (map)" them between 0 and 1. These values will be sent to the Filter cutoff.

4) Connect the output of 'Noise' to the 'in' input of the filter and turn the "MIX WET<>DRY" knob to 0 to hear the effect of this random cutoff filter on the noise."}},"267":{"type":"Mul","name":"Mul VOL","x":2232,"y":2874,"ins":[],"inNames":[],"outNames":[""],"params":{"minVal":0,"maxVal":0.2,"value":0.02098437500000004,"deviceId":null,"controlId":null}},"302":{"type":"Nop","name":"Nop","x":745,"y":2872,"ins":[null],"inNames":[""],"outNames":[""],"params":{}},"304":{"type":"Notes","name":"Rem 3","x":51,"y":2995,"ins":[],"inNames":[],"outNames":[],"params":{"text":"The 'Noise' generator produces at a very high frequency random values between -1 and 1. The resulting wave sounds like noise.

This noise is rich in all kinds of frequencies and can be reduced to some of them with a filter.

The fact that it produces random values can be exploited to generate such values at a desired frequency thanks to the 'hold' node which will keep its input value when activated via 'trig' until it is activated again in the same way.

Here, when the 'pulse' generates the value 1, it activates the 'hold'. This random value N of the interval [-1;1] is then "projected (mapped)" by the function (N+1)/2 on the interval [0;1] so as to be able to give the 'cutoff' of the filter the adequate or desired values. Such numerical transformations (+ and /) or (+ and *) (* and -) by projection (mappings) are very useful to modulate certain parameters with the help of inputs from various sources.

The 'pulse' allows here also to provide a 'gate' to the ADSR which gives via the 'Mul' an amplitude envelope to the filtered sound.

Finally, the value of the "MIX WET<>DRY" button is used in such a way, via the 'Sub' node, that 

The WET volume = 1 - The DRY volume. 

So when WET = 0, then DRY = 1 and vice versa...

This process is very useful to mix the signals of two sound sources at your convenience, for example.

Finally, as indicated, the 'Nop' node is a node without effect, it only allows to redirect signals in the synthesizer in order to organize and clarify its structure.

Attention: The noise sound is very rich in frequencies of all kinds, it also has a very high sound volume compared to other wave generators. The OUT VOL setting is therefore quite low."}},"305":{"type":"AudioOut","name":"AudioOut","x":1435,"y":466,"ins":[["156",0],["156",0]],"inNames":["left","right"],"outNames":[],"params":{}}}}
